channel.title: Course Introduction & Tools on GA Javascript
channel.description: Recent content in Course Introduction & Tools on GA Javascript

item.title: Objectives
item.description: Understand what the term “front-end Development” means Introduce tools you will be using throughout the class Cover class logistics, structure & keys to success

item.title: What Is front-end Development?
item.description: Overview Front-end web development, also known as client-side development is the practice of producing HTML, CSS and JavaScript for a website or Web Application so that a user can see and interact with them directly. What are the primary technologies associated with front-end development? HTML CSS Javascript How is front-end development differ from back-end development? Backend development, is also known as server-side development and involves storing data on behalf of users or customers

item.title: Class Logistics & Materials
Course Tools
item.description: Text Editor: Why?: Text editor is a program that developers use to create and edit a range of programming language files. We’ll be using Atom, because it’s open source (free) and really good. Download Atom Browser: Why?: Google chrome is a robust browser with a variety of tools that are helpful to developers. Install Google Chrome Github: Why?: Github (and Git) are tools/applications used to by developers to manage their code and work collaboratively with each other.

item.title: Folder Organization
item.description: Recommended Folder Organization Create a folder in your Documents (My Documents on Windows) folder called FEWD At beginning of every class, download and unzip (mac instructions | windows instructions) the “Lesson Files” for that lesson directly into your FEWD folder While the lesson files will be hosted on Dropbox, you do not need to have a dropbox account to download the files. As the course progresses you’ll have a neatly organized listing of all of your work that looks similar to this:

item.title: Keys to Success
item.description: Do your homework: More you practice the concepts learned in class, the faster you’ll pick them up Don’t try to memorize anything: You’ll memorize things naturally through the act of doing things over and over again. Besides, if you don’t remember something just look it up (i.e. google). Work smarter not harder: In additional to looking things up, developers are really good at referencing past code that they’ve used in the past to solve problems they encounter in the present.
